author: By Valerie Hopkins and Emile Ducke
title: They Endured One Russian Occupation. Now, They Fear a Second.
description: The torture rooms in the battered Ukrainian city of Kupiansk have been empty for months. But Moscow’s advancing forces are just five miles away.
content: A billboard at the main entrance to the city of Kupiansk illustrates the tenuous nature of Ukrainian control in a region that has become one of the most active parts of the 750-mile front line in the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: How Super Is Your Superpower?
description: Is China now #1, or does America still lead? Yes.
content: My most recent column was about the troubles facing the Chinese economy, which appear to be serious. However, I was careful to acknowledge that China’s three-decade economic miracle has made it a bona fide economic superpower and that its current problems aren’t likely to change that fact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: China’s Stalling Economy Puts the World on Notice
description: As China’s economy flashes indications of decline, the consequences pose perils for countries around the globe.
content: For more than a quarter-century, China has been synonymous with relentless development and upward mobility. As its 1.4 billion people gained an appetite for the wares of the world — Hollywood movies, South Korean electronics, iron ore mined in Australia — the global economy was propelled by a seemingly inexhaustible engine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: A Premier League Love Story Has Heartbreak Ahead
description: Luton Town’s rise to the world’s richest soccer league proves England’s fabled merit system still works. What happens next may show that it does not.
content: Within a few days of Luton Town’s promotion to the Premier League in May, the construction crews were moving in and the scaffolding was going up at its stadium, Kenilworth Road. The club’s first home game in English soccer’s top flight since its money-spinning, supercharged rebrand into the richest, most popular league in the world was not quite three months away. There was an alarming amount of work to do, and not nearly enough time to do it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: It Took $1.7 Billion to Fix Fire Island’s Beaches. One Storm Wrecked Them.
description: The barrier island off the coast of New York is more than a vacation community. It is what stands between rising seas and one of the most densely populated coastal regions in the country.
content: Just a few years ago, the beach at Fire Island Pines was almost as wide as a football field, the result of a $1.7-billion government project to combat erosion on the South Shore of Long Island after Hurricane Sandy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: Wrestling With Identity at the Edinburgh Festival
description: In plays from Scotland, Korea and Switzerland, theater companies explored questions of belonging, with varying degrees of success.
content: Questions of nationhood, identity and belonging loom large in three politically themed productions at this year’s Edinburgh International Festival. The tagline for this year’s edition is “community over chaos,” and there was plenty of both in “Thrown,” a National Theater of Scotland production running at the Traverse Theater through Aug. 27.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan and Ken Belson
title: The N.F.L.’s Betting Crackdown Has Followed Players to Training Camp
description: Some within the sport think the league’s discipline for betting has been heavy-handed. But that has meant more presentations, not softer rules.
content: Cameron Heyward, the veteran Pittsburgh Steelers defensive lineman, remembers that when he was selected in the first round of the 2011 N.F.L. draft, the most popular betting event was the N.C.A.A. Division I men’s basketball tournament, which attracts millions of casual fans in the United States through bracket pools among friends and co-workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: When art and money meet
description: Encouragement, profit or exploitation?
content: I’ve often thought that if one was looking for niche curses  to place on enemies,  “May you be profiled by Patrick Radden Keefe” would be a particularly potent option. The New Yorker staff writer and author has written with devastating precision about the Sacklers, the wealthy family who reaped billions from America’s devastating opioid epidemic; Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug-cartel kingpin known as “El Chapo”; and Gerry Adams, the Irish Republican activist turned politician.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Sophia Lanman, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Diane Wong
title: Don’t Scrape Me, Bro, the Activists Sabotaging Self-Driving Cars and How Reddit Beat a Rebellion
description: Backlash to technology online and on the streets.
content: Users are protesting Zoom’s liberal data-collection policy. Authors are shutting down websites that scrape their work. And, in a concession to users, OpenAI is allowing websites to opt out of web scraping. The era of A.I. backlash has begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Oprah Winfrey Distributes Aid at a Maui Shelter
description: Residents have been urging the billionaires and celebrities who own homes on Maui to support relief efforts.
content: Oprah Winfrey, who has been a part-time resident of Maui for more than 15 years, distributed supplies on Thursday at the War Memorial Stadium in Wailuku, which is being used to shelter evacuees from the island’s deadly wildfires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: DeSantis Is Heckled During Iowa Bus Tour
description: The Florida governor was greeted by two women with cowbells and a bullhorn, shouting criticism of his policies as he prepared to visit the Iowa State Fair.
content: Ron DeSantis’s six-stop bus tour began inauspiciously on Friday, when he was drowned out by two women who heckled the Florida governor with cowbells and a bullhorn during his first event of the day, about 40 miles west of Des Moines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Granville
title: U.K. Economy Grows Weakly
description: A small acceleration in the second quarter was better than analysts had expected.
content: The British economy grew 0.2 percent in the April-to-June period from the previous quarter, a small increase that beat some forecasts as the country continues to deal with high inflation and rising interest rates. It was an incremental acceleration over the first quarter of the year, when the economy expanded just 0.1 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: She Once Ran Against Putin. Her Advice Now: Resistance Is Futile
description: Ksenia Sobchak, one of the best known media figures still in Russia, says her fatalistic stance just reflects a grim reality. Some liberals call her a Kremlin stooge, while hawks see her as disloyal.
content: Emerging from a friend’s Maserati on southern Spain’s Mediterranean coast, Ksenia Sobchak wants the world to know: Back home in Russia, fighting for change is futile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellie Pithers
title: In Paris, an Apartment With a Rebellious Streak
description: The architect Maxime Bousquet has reimagined a portion of a grand 17th-century building as a fittingly irreverent home for a young gallerist.
content: When it comes to aesthetics, says the Paris-based architect and interior designer Maxime Bousquet, 35, “what’s considered good taste is not always interesting.” Since starting his own firm in 2019 — after stints working for the fashion brand Kenzo, the architect Joseph Dirand and the architecture office Studio KO — he has made a subtly iconoclastic approach and an obsession with detail hallmarks of his practice. He’s opened up the roof of a triplex in Paris’s Eighth Arrondissement to create a dramatic terrace and entirely reconfigured a narrow, jewel-box-like house in the city’s Invalides area. It helps that most of his clients are creative 30-something Parisians who, while well-versed in traditional European design, are seeking something more offbeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Teenager Pleads Not Guilty in Hate Crime Killing of Gay Dancer
description: A lawyer for Dmitriy Popov said he might pursue a self-defense argument in a case stemming from a deadly dispute at a Brooklyn gas station.
content: The 17-year-old charged with murder as a hate crime in the fatal stabbing last month of a gay Black dancer at a Brooklyn gas station pleaded not guilty at an arraignment on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maura Kelly
title: Where Everybody Knows Your Name
description: How becoming a regular at a neighborhood shop soothed my loneliness.
content: Surely my friend Amy would rescue me. She was a roll-up-your-sleeves-and-conquer-the-world kind of person, crushing it in her own career; if anyone could help me solve what was wrong in my life — which was more or less everything — she could.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: David Balton and Jane Stewart bring us a behemoth of a puzzle, but we can take it down.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage is from Malcolm Gladwell’s “David and Goliath: Underdogs, Misfits, and the Art of Battling Giants.” It’s a book from 2013 that concerns the allure of the underdog and the idea that, in many cases, the superficially dominant side of a battle is often eminently beatable. The passage itself is a bit of a cliffhanger! As soon as I had solved it, I looked online for the next few sentences to find a bit of context. This book has a following — there are lots of references on inspirational LinkedIn and pop culture posts — so I learned that poor Goliath was actually ill equipped to defend against David’s sling of rocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Engelhart
title: I’ve Reported on Dementia for Years, and One Image of a Prisoner Keeps Haunting Me
description: America’s prisons are filling up with people who are so old, they don’t remember their crimes.
content: At Federal Medical Center Devens, a federal prison in Massachusetts, there is a prisoner who thinks he is a warden. “I’m the boss. I’m going to fire you,” Victor Orena, who is 89, will tell the prison staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Before Joining Federal Safety Program, Freight Railroads Push to Change It
description: After the derailment in East Palestine, Ohio, the nation’s major freight railroads agreed to join a federal program for workers to report safety issues. But first, they want it to be overhauled.
content: After a freight train carrying toxic chemicals derailed in East Palestine, Ohio, in February, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg secured what seemed like a significant victory. Following years of resistance, the nation’s largest freight railroads agreed to participate in a federal safety program that allows employees to confidentially report safety issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: ‘Big Brother’ Contestant Is Expelled for Using Racial Slur
description: “Well, I’m in trouble now,” Luke Valentine said after using a slur for Black people in a conversation on the reality show.
content: “Big Brother,” CBS’s long-running reality competition, has kicked off a contestant for using a racial slur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Dreaming Big
description: John-Clark Levin opens our solving weekend.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
title: Judge Limits Trump’s Ability to Share Jan. 6 Evidence
description: During a 90-minute hearing in Washington, Judge Tanya S. Chutkan also warned the former president against any attempt to intimidate witnesses or prejudice potential jurors.
content: The federal judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s prosecution on charges of seeking to overturn the 2020 election rejected his request on Friday to be able to speak broadly about evidence and witnesses — and warned Mr. Trump she would take necessary “measures” to keep him from intimidating witnesses or tainting potential jurors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Describes China as a Time Bomb Over Economic Problems
description: The sharply worded comments are the latest example of the president’s willingness to criticize China even as he tries to ease tensions.
content: President Biden warned on Thursday that China’s struggles with high unemployment and an aging work force make the country a “ticking time bomb” at the heart of the world economy and a potential threat to other nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Hunter Biden Case
description: An example of America’s dueling realities.
content: The Hunter Biden case has become the latest example of America’s dueling realities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: This Isn’t Barbie’s First Time Onscreen: She’s Been a Movie Star for Decades
description: Before Margot Robbie’s live-action take on the doll, Mattel put out more than a dozen animated films that have an avid following, even now.
content: Every Christmas season starting when I was 5, my sister and I had a go-to movie: “Barbie in the Nutcracker.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek, Jordyn Holman, DeSean McClinton-Holland and Maggie Shannon
title: Make the Whole Place Shimmer: America Spends Big for Beyoncé and Taylor Swift
description: The artists’ fans have been shelling out on lavish wardrobes, parties and travel, generating business and boosting spending in host cities.
content: Beyoncé told us that girls run the world. This summer, she and Taylor Swift seemed to prove it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: What to Know About the New Dominant Covid Variant
description: EG.5 is spreading quickly, but experts say it’s no more dangerous than previous versions.
content: Concern is rising about the Covid-19 variant EG.5. This week, it became the dominant variant in the United States, and the World Health Organization classified EG.5 as a “variant of interest,” meaning it has genetic changes that give it an advantage and its prevalence is growing. So how worried should people be about it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 10: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by Aug. 18 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 29.
content: Welcome to the tenth and final week of our 14th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: 47 Weapons Seized as California Judge Is Charged in Killing of His Wife
description: “I just lost it. I just shot my wife,” Judge Jeffrey Ferguson of Orange County Superior Court texted his clerk and bailiff, according to court records.
content: A Southern California judge accused of killing his wife texted his court clerk and bailiff admitting to the killing, prosecutors said on Friday as they charged him with murder and weapon possession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Vivek Ramaswamy Has a Gimmick That Republicans Are Sure to Love
description: Rather than persuade younger voters, the candidate would just disenfranchise the vast majority of them.
content: Vivek Ramaswamy is a 38-year-old investor and former pharmaceutical executive who wants to be the Republican nominee for president. He’s not ahead by any means, but he’s doing better than you might expect. If Donald Trump dominates the field and Ron DeSantis is the far runner-up, then Ramaswamy is the candidate poised to rise if the Florida governor falls further behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Birria tacos and icy Micheladas, spicy corn on the cob and tender peach cobbler
description: Recipes that remind you that summer, for all its troubles, is the greatest time of the year.
content: Good morning. These are the days of miracle and wonder, Paul Simon sings through the device on the counter. This is the long-distance call. It is the highest of summer where I am, torpor is afoot, and all I want to do is bubble some birria de res (above) on the stove in advance of a dinner of tacos and Micheladas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: Decaying Tanker in Mideast Is Emptied of Oil, Averting Catastrophic Spill
description: More than a million barrels of oil on a tanker off the coast of Yemen were transferred to another ship bought by the United Nations. But now a new hurdle looms: Who owns the recovered oil?
content: A United Nations operation to transfer more than one million barrels of oil from a decaying tanker into another ship off the coast of Yemen has been completed, officials said on Friday, averting a catastrophic spill that could have devastated marine life and communities across the Red Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Iowa’s Republican Governor Offers Candidates a Safe Space at the Fair
description: Gov. Kim Reynolds of Iowa is hosting “chats” at the Iowa State Fair, providing the Republican contenders with a friendly forum to connect with voters.
content: Gov. Kim Reynolds of Iowa did not ask former Vice President Mike Pence about Donald J. Trump’s indictments, the topic about which he is most often grilled on the campaign trail. Nor did she ask him if his life had changed “since Tucker Carlson ruined your career,” as one voter shouted during his appearance at the political soapbox Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Madeleine Ngo
title: Yellow Says It Will Repay Federal Debt. Legal Experts Are Skeptical.
description: The trucking company, which has filed for bankruptcy protection, owes more than $700 million to the Treasury Department.
content: Yellow, a trucking company that filed for bankruptcy protection on Sunday, told a judge this week that it would fully repay the $729 million it owed the federal government by selling warehouses, trucks and other assets. But with its industry in a downturn, Yellow could struggle to get top dollar for its assets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Livia Albeck-Ripka and Orlando Mayorquin
title: Some Fire Survivors Say Flames Reached Them Before Evacuation Orders
description: A fire near Lahaina that had initially been contained flared up again and threatened homes, but some residents said they received no evacuation orders.
content: The death toll from the fires that overtook Maui was already growing significantly on Thursday as questions mounted over whether officials had acted with enough urgency to evacuate the tourist haven of Lahaina, where many people described harrowing escapes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: How Christian Cooper, the Central Park Birder, Spends His Sundays
description: The author and host of “Extraordinary Birder” enjoys a meditative moment, complete with lute music, among the native plants in his rooftop garden.
content: Christian Cooper may be best known as the Black birder whose altercation with a white woman in Central Park in 2020 escalated into a national news story. But he’s also a longtime gay activist and author who previously wrote and edited for Marvel Comics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
title: China’s Military, ‘Chasing the Dream,’ Probes Taiwan’s Defenses
description: Day by day, the People’s Liberation Army is turning up the pressure, deploying an ever-wider array of planes and ships.
content: China has been steadily intensifying military pressure on Taiwan over the past year, sending jets, drones, bombers and other planes farther and in greater numbers to extend an intimidating presence all around the island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: An Attack Over Vogueing Resonates Painfully With a Renowned Drag Performer
description: Kevin Aviance’s song was sampled on the Beyoncé album that O’Shae Sibley was dancing to before he was killed. The connection felt deeper than that coincidence.
content: On a Saturday night in high summer, O’Shae Sibley paid the highest possible price for a visibility that, as a 28-year-old gay Black man, he assumed was rightfully his in New York more than two decades into the 21st century. It was 33 years after Madonna’s “Vogue” became an international hit single, and whatever was being done to limit L.G.B.T.Q. rights in so many other parts of the country, he lived in a place where the City Council had not long ago ousted a Queens Republican from the chamber’s committee on mental health after she criticized taxpayer-funded drag-queen story hours in public schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: What Makes Penne Alla Vodka So Delicious? It’s All in the Sauce.
description: The exact origin story of vodka sauce is uncertain, but its legacy is bold, spicy and ubiquitous.
content: In the 1980s, long before he became a New York chef, a young Iacopo Falai lived across the hall from a hip uncle who sometimes made penne alla vodka for dinner. The combination of tomato, cream and chile wasn’t traditional by any means, especially in Florence, where he lived, but his uncle was a travel-loving caterer who introduced Mr. Falai to a world of foods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: For President Biden, a Political Liability That May Not Go Away Soon
description: The collapse of a plea deal and the appointment of a special counsel to investigate Hunter Biden mean the president could face political fallout for months to come.
content: They thought it was over, that they could put it in the rearview mirror. All that Hunter Biden had to do was show up in a courtroom, answer a few questions, sign some paperwork and that would be it. Not that the Republicans would let it go, but any real danger would be past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Dreading That Event You Said Yes to Ages Ago? Be Kinder to Your ‘Future Self.’
description: Experts share five tips for making (and keeping) commitments.
content: I signed up for a “fun run” three months ago. Now the event is lurking on my calendar as I run through excuses to get out of it. I want to be the sort of person who runs miles for pleasure. I am not. Why, then, did I say yes in the first place?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Maui Fires Come at a Moment of Turmoil for the Insurance Industry
description: Hawaii has the nation’s lowest rates for homeowner coverage because it has not suffered many natural disasters. That may change.
content: The devastating wildfires in Hawaii have come at a time of upheaval for the insurance industry, in a place that had not been considered very risky by underwriters.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Fast Car’ and 5 More Cross-Generational Covers
description: With Luke Combs’s version of Tracy Chapman’s hit at No. 2 on the Hot 100, revisit the origins of Björk, the Clash and Nirvana songs.
content: This summer, a lot of people who were born after 1988 are discovering who Tracy Chapman is thanks to Luke Combs’s hit cover of her classic “Fast Car,” which currently sits at No. 2 on the Billboard Hot 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: W. Jason Morgan, 87, Dies; Developed the Theory of Plate Tectonics
description: His framework offered a new way to think about continental drift and revolutionized the study of earthquakes, volcanoes and evolution.
content: W. Jason Morgan, who in 1967 developed the theory of plate tectonics — a framework that revolutionized the study of earthquakes, volcanoes and the slow, steady shift of the continents across the earth’s mantle — died on July 31 at his home in Natick, Mass. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 7 Premiere Recap: Axe Is Back
description: A certain redheaded maniac returns to the scene for the series’s concluding season. Let the final showdowns begin.
content: He’s back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: kafkaesque
description: This word has appeared in 20 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word kafkaesque has appeared in 20 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 25 in “Spotify Wants to Get Into Audiobooks but Says Apple Is in the Way” by Tripp Mickle:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Philip Cheung
title: A Journey Through Lahaina’s Endless Streets of Suffering
description: A historic Hawaiian town that was once home to 13,000 people is now a desolate ruin. With the death toll rising, the true scope of the tragedy is still unfolding.
content: Along the empty streets of Lahaina, the warped shells of vehicles sit as if frozen in time, some of them still in the middle of the road, pointed toward escapes that were cut short. Others stand in driveways next to houses that are now piles of ash, many still smoldering with acrid smoke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: U.S. to Fund a $1.2 Billion Effort to Vacuum Greenhouse Gases From the Sky
description: Many scientists are skeptical of the technology, and environmentalists have criticized the approach.
content: The Biden administration will spend $1.2 billion to help build the nation’s first two commercial-scale plants to vacuum carbon dioxide pollution from the atmosphere, a nascent technology that some scientists say could be a breakthrough in the fight against global warming, but that others fear is an extravagant boondoggle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Scenes From the Hawaii Fires and the Aftermath
description: The historic town of Lahaina was devastated by the fires that moved through the island of Maui this week.
content: As the sun rose on Friday in Hawaii, firefighters were still working to fully contain flare-ups from the fast-moving wildfires that devastated the historic oceanside town of Lahaina and other parts of Maui. Emergency workers prepared to resume their search for victims in scorched areas.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Swallowed by a Whale, and Other August Books
description: Sarah Lyall discusses the thriller “Whalefall,” by Daniel Kraus, and Joumana Khatib rounds up the month’s other big books.
content: If you remember your grade school English lessons, then you know that “man vs. nature” is one of the standby plotlines for storytellers, from “To Build a Fire” to “The Martian.” For readers, the appeal of such stories often lies in the “nature” side of that equation: The more daunting the conditions, the more fun it is to read about the hero’s attempt to survive them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Summer Camp Therapy and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
description: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Kevin Yamamura
title: California Mourns a Wildfire Disaster in Maui
description: The state that has recently suffered some of the worst wildfires in American history will lend its expertise to Hawaii.
content: The first videos showed residents fleeing through walls of fire, frantically trying to escape a disaster that caught many of them off guard. Then came reports of people leaping into the Pacific Ocean as flames engulfed Lahaina, a historic seaside town on the Hawaiian island of Maui.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: What Another Trump Presidency Could Mean for Australia
description: The author of a new book exploring that possibility says it would raise existential questions about the current alliance with America, with huge implications for Australia’s regional and global standing.
content: If Donald Trump secures the Republican nomination and wins the U.S. presidential election in 2024, what could that mean for Australia: for our regional security, our political culture, our democracy? How likely is it, anyway? And with that possibility looming, what should we start thinking about and doing now?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Luke Broadwater and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Garland Appoints Weiss as Special Counsel in Hunter Biden Inquiry
description: The attorney general said he decided to elevate David C. Weiss after the prosecutor informed him that the powers of a special counsel were necessary to continue the investigation.
content: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland on Friday elevated the federal prosecutor investigating President Biden’s son Hunter to the status of special counsel after negotiations to revive a plea agreement on tax and gun charges foundered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: ‘We’re All Water-Bottle Freaks’
description: Americans are drinking more water. How best to contain it: That’s the burning question.
content: Carrie Frost is well equipped for hydration. A registered nurse and a mother of two from Colorado, she estimates that her family has accumulated “upward of 25 to 30” reusable flasks at home for keeping cold drinks: flasks large and small, of various designs and colors, with a straw and without. But last month, as she sat in 90-degree heat at her son’s travel baseball tournament, she drank from a plastic water bottle that she had purchased for $3 at a local grocery store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: Company Recalls Ice Cream Products Over Listeria Contamination Concerns
description: Health officials are investigating whether the Soft Serve on the Go brand, produced by Real Kosher Ice Cream, was behind an outbreak of listeria, a bacteria that can cause serious illness.
content: An ice cream company based in Brooklyn has issued a recall of all flavors of its soft serve ice cream and sorbet brand after two people who ate its vanilla chocolate flavor fell sick and were sent to the hospital, according to the company and health officials. The illnesses were possibly linked to listeria, a type of bacteria that can cause serious sickness in people 65 or older and miscarriages and premature births in pregnant women, health officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: See How They Held Off Flames at a Haven for Hawaii’s Endangered Birds
description: A conservationist and a neighbor defended the center, part of an effort to save the state’s native birds from extinction, until firefighters arrived.
content: Jennifer Pribble was asleep when the power line fell in the forest. She heard the generator kick in but didn’t think much of it. High winds sometimes led to electricity failures. It was normal enough. Wildfires were not even on her radar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Spencer
title: How ‘Red, White & Royal Blue’ Reimagined a BookTok Sensation
description: The filmmakers didn’t want to disappoint fans of Casey McQuiston’s novel about the romance between a U.S. president’s son and a British prince.
content: On most Fridays, the Victoria & Albert Museum in London closes at 10 p.m. sharp. But one night last summer, after all of the tourists had spilled back onto the streets of South Kensington, two men slow-danced among the Berninis and Rodins until the sun rose the next morning. A cover of “Can’t Help Falling in Love” by the indie-pop singer Perfume Genius echoed through the sculpture hall, soundtracking their tender moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: A Happiness That Took 90 Years to Achieve
description: When Kenneth Felts began work on a memoir at age 90, he found himself filled with regrets over a secret gay love affair. So he came out — privately and publicly — which inspired Johnny Hau to do the same.
content: A decade ago, Johnny Javier Hau Dzib took a nighttime drive around his Denver neighborhood, his mind in a suicidal thought loop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: With Only 475 Square Feet, She Had to Make Every Inch Count
description: Finding an apartment in Brooklyn isn’t easy, but one interior designer had an advantage over other buyers: She wasn’t afraid to live in a tiny space.
content: After years of renting apartments in Brooklyn, Alex Kalita was finally ready to buy in 2017. The idea of investing in real estate was appealing, but as the founder of Common Bond Design, an interiors firm, she also wanted the opportunity to renovate, so her home could reflect her sense of style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: A Hidden Currency of Incalculable Worth
description: We need to start thinking about policies aimed at freeing up time for impoverished families as a form of aid.
content: Poverty is the great thief of time, robbing parents of hours spent with their children. It takes them away from sporting events, choir concerts, ballet recitals, afternoon homework and watching Saturday morning cartoons, snuggled on the couch in pajamas. Despite the indestructible myth of the poor as lazy, many heads of struggling families endure long, unpredictable hours for little pay to provide for their offspring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lux Alptraum
title: Teens Don’t Really Understand That the World Can See What They Do Online, but I Do
description: Teenagers are inevitably going to make mistakes online. I know, because it happened to me, and here’s what I wish adults had done about it.
content: When Matthew McConaughey and his wife, Camila Alves McConaughey, took to Instagram to jointly announce a new venture this summer, you might have expected it to be an upcoming film or a fledgling lifestyle brand. Their news was more unusual: the unveiling of an official Instagram account for their son Levi, which they were giving to him on his 15th birthday, long after many of his friends had signed up, they noted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Rysman
title: Savoring Maremma, a Quiet Corner of Italy
description: Whether on horseback, by bike or on foot, the least populated part of Tuscany offers a pastoral escape, where your days follow the cycles of the weather, animals and plants.
content: I woke up to the braying of donkeys. Opening the window to morning air perfumed by wisteria and honeysuckle, I could see the herd — 16 sweet-eyed animals in all — grazing by the olive groves of La Pescaia, a country estate turned idyllic inn that embodies a fantasy of pastoral happiness for me: life among animals and bird song and olive trees, encircled by the rugged nature of Maremma, in Italy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: A Retirement Puzzle: Turning Over Control of Your Money
description: It’s difficult to know when to get help managing finances. Communicating with loved ones, even when you don’t want to, is the first step.
content: At a visit in 2021 with her primary care doctor, Donna Purchase hesitated before answering a routine question. Her daughter Deborah Smith, who was with her, raised her eyebrows. Her mother had been forgetful lately, she said, and Ms. Smith was concerned. Ms. Purchase, who is now 78, left with a referral for a memory test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: Sweden Ousts Japan, Ensuring World Cup Will Have First-Time Champion
description: Sweden followed up its elimination of the United States by holding off Japan, the last former winner in the field.
content: A Women’s World Cup of change, of unexpected early departures and tantalizing arrivals, has completed its upending of certainty and tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Ukraine Says Debris From Downed Missile Fell on Grounds of Kyiv Hospital
description: The Ukrainian Air Force said that three other missiles were aimed at military airfields in the western part of the country.
content: Ukraine said its air defenses shot down a ballistic missile over Kyiv on Friday, a rare midmorning assault on the Ukrainian capital as Russia stepped up its assaults on towns and cities across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: A New FAFSA Form Is Coming, Along With Changes in College Aid
description: In addition to the new form, the federal government will expand eligibility for federal aid in the biggest overhaul in decades.
content: A long-awaited, supposedly user-friendly version of the college financial aid form known as the FAFSA will be unveiled for the 2024-25 school year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Republican 2024 Hopefuls Scoff at Hunter Biden Special Counsel Move
description: Candidates, including Donald J. Trump, cast doubt on the newly-named special counsel’s independence.
content: Republican presidential candidates, some of whom were stumping in the early-caucusing state of Iowa on Friday, largely derided the news that the prosecutor investigating President Biden’s son Hunter had been elevated to special counsel status.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Americans Held Prisoner in Iran Saw Promise of Better Relations
description: The five Americans who are part of a prisoner swap could be released by September under a complicated agreement with Tehran.
content: When Siamak Namazi traveled to Tehran in the summer of 2015, Iran had just signed a landmark nuclear deal and the government was encouraging expatriates to return home and bring their expertise and dollars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lovia Gyarkye
title: Frank Bowling’s Geographies
description: The restless innovation of the influential painter is on display in a retrospective in California.
content: Look how the yellow falls in Frank Bowling’s two mammoth paintings titled “Middle Passage,” both produced in 1970. See how in one of them, the color meets the red to make an orange that resembles the sun just before it fades from the sky? The yellow can’t stay in one place. It’s restless, much like the Guyanese artist responsible for its trek. At the bottom of the canvas, the yellow reveals a shape, an outline of Bowling’s home country. Squint and the whole of South America hovers in the distance. Africa, too. The yellow ends its journey by mingling with a green as crisp as grass stains. Together, they make a color that, from some angles, looks black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: When One Partner Wants Sex More Than the Other
description: Libido differences are a common part of relationships, sex therapists say. Here’s how to manage.
content: Frances and her wife have been together for more than 40 years, and early on in their relationship they couldn’t keep their hands off each other. Then came three children and a series of health issues (along with accompanying medications) that slowly eroded her wife’s libido.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Evacuates Asylum Seekers From Barge Over Bacteria in Water
description: Bacteria that can cause Legionnaires’ disease were found on the Bibby Stockholm, a barge that began housing migrants this week as part of a hard-line government policy.
content: Just four days ago, asylum seekers were moved onto an austere barge moored off the British coast as the government rolled out a new policy aimed at illustrating its tough approach on migration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Fresh Fighting in Ethiopia Leads Israel to Evacuate More Than 200
description: Less than a year after the war in the country’s northern Tigray region ended, Ethiopia’s military is battling an ethnic militia in the neighboring Amhara region in a part of Africa already ravaged by conflict.
content: Fighting between Ethiopia’s military and a local ethnic militia in the northwestern Amhara region has intensified in recent weeks, pushing the government to block the internet and declare a state of emergency and leading Israel to evacuate more than 200 Ethiopian Jews and Israelis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Heart of Stone’ Review: Mission Improbable
description: Gal Gadot plays an international superspy who teams up with an all-powerful computer in this ludicrous and derivative Netflix espionage thriller.
content: In the early going, “Heart of Stone” seems like a pretty routine action thriller about spies. Gal Gadot stars as Rachel Stone, a rookie hacker for an MI6 unit; when we meet her in the movie’s opening sequence, she’s in the middle of a covert mission to ensnare an arms dealer in the Italian Alps, ferrying her elite squad of operatives past high-tech security systems, mainly by tapping away at a computer, looking very serious and saying stuff like “writing a new access code … the system’s offline!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I’ve Hidden My Trust Fund for 15 Years. Do I Finally Tell My Spouse?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on telling the truth about a big secret.
content: I am a 44-year-old man and have been married to my spouse for 10 years. We’ve been together for 15. Unbeknown to my spouse, I have a trust fund that provides me with a monthly income of $25,000. When we first met, I said that I worked as a consultant, and they have never questioned this. My spouse, a dedicated doctor, works long hours and doesn’t like to discuss work when not on the job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Friday Briefing
description: The toll from wildfires in Hawaii.
content: More than 50 people have died in devastating wildfires on the Hawaii island of Maui. Survivors described fleeing for their lives from a fast-moving “total inferno” that left the town of Lahaina in smoking ruins. Thousands of people filled evacuation shelters, and tourists continued a grim exodus to the airport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: A Timeline of Hunter Biden’s Life and Legal Troubles
description: Mr. Biden, 53, has acknowledged a decades-long addiction to alcohol and crack cocaine. His foreign business dealings have led to questions about President Biden’s influence.
content: With the news that the Justice Department has named a special counsel to investigate a wide range of conduct by President Biden’s son Hunter Biden, his life is bound to come under even more intense scrutiny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: The Latest Migrant Battleground: New York City Soccer Fields
description: Mayor Eric Adams has urged New Yorkers to join him in raising their voices about the migrant crisis. More of them are — against him.
content: For months, as New York City has struggled to find shelter for more than 50,000 migrants, Mayor Eric Adams has sought to rally residents to push Washington for more help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: A Former Weed Dealer Built the ‘Budega’ Brand. Then Copycats Moved In.
description: Alex Norman’s fight to protect the brand he created is part of a trend that industry lawyers say threatens small cannabis businesses.
content: In the fall of 2021, an acquaintance of Alex Norman, the founder of a cannabis apparel and lifestyle brand called Budega NYC, reached out to congratulate him on making a deal to open several dispensaries in Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 11, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Aug. 11, 2023.
content: A Critic’s Notebook article on Wednesday about three popular musical revivals misstated the year in which “The Rocky Horror Show” was produced at the Stratford Festival. It was in 2018, not 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should Trump’s Jan. 6 Trial Be Televised?
description: Readers offer different opinions and propose alternatives. Also: The Republican loyalty pledge; pig farming; driverless cabs; homesick at camp.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Make Room for the Bucket Bag
description: The classic accessory returns in styles ranging from sturdy to slouchy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh and Reid J. Epstein
title: How Are Iowa Democrats? ‘I Can’t Even Describe to You How Bad It Is.’
description: As Republican presidential candidates flock to the state, Democrats there are despondent, exhausted by repeated defeats and the loss of their first-in-the-nation nominating contest.
content: Not long ago, Iowa was the center of the Democratic political universe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saskia Solomon
title: The Frothy Saga of the Jacuzzi Family
description: An immigrant story, an American dream, a machine that defined bourgeois sensuality.
content: Candido Jacuzzi didn’t set out to turn his last name into a global brand. Nor did he intend to power a business which, though it created the family fortune, nearly tore them apart. He just wanted to ease the physical pain suffered by his son, any way he could.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Jamie Reid, 76, Dies; His Anarchic Graphics Helped Define the Sex Pistols
description: He created some of the most controversial — and celebrated — artwork of the punk era, which outraged polite British society almost as much as the band’s music did.
content: Jamie Reid, whose searing cover art and other graphics for the Sex Pistols, featuring ransom-note lettering and defaced images of the queen, outraged polite British society nearly as much as the seminal punk band’s anarchic anthems and obscenity-laced tirades, died on Tuesday at his home in Liverpool. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Hell Hath No Fury Like a Writer Who Gets a Speeding Ticket
description: David Simon, creator of “The Wire,” was livid that he got a $50 ticket for going 36 miles per hour in a school zone. His response drew a lot of responses.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at a dust-up on social media about a speeding ticket. We’ll also look at inflation in New York and increases in subway and bus fares that take effect on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin P. Clarke
title: If Your Country Is Falling Apart, the Wagner Group Will Be There
description: The ouster of Mohamed Bazoum by Niger’s military presents an important opportunity to Russia’s Wagner group.
content: In July, the Russian mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin released a video from his new base in Belarus, welcoming his fighters to their country of exile after the Wagner group’s ill-fated mutiny. He also told them to prepare — for “a new journey to Africa.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Driverless Taxis Can Expand San Francisco Services, Regulators Say
description: Autonomous Cruise and Waymo cars have been buzzing around the city for some time, and now can offer paid rides throughout it around the clock.
content: California regulators agreed on Thursday to the expansion of driverless taxi services in San Francisco, despite the safety concerns of local officials and community activists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: Mapping Out Their Future on a Spreadsheet
description: After 16 years together, Sachi Takahashi-Rial and George Carollo drew up a timeline, which included a decision to legally tie the knot in 2023.
content: Sachi Alita Takahashi-Rial and George Carl Gaetano Carollo sent out their online wedding invitations in March, which left some people amused, and others guessing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Fox’s Chief Legal Officer Will Depart
description: Viet Dinh, an influential force inside the company, advised it through its $787.5 million settlement with Dominion Voting Systems.
content: Fox Corporation’s chief legal officer, Viet Dinh, will depart at the end of the year, in a major shake-up at the company after the landmark $787.5 million settlement it paid to Dominion Voting Systems in April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: A Chimp Sanctuary With a New Urgency to Give Shelter
description: Emily Anthes, a science reporter, visited a chimpanzee sanctuary in Louisiana to observe how it prepares the animals for extreme weather.
content: Since she began working at The New York Times in 2021, Emily Anthes has written about African malaria mosquitoes, video-chatting parrots, California condor parents, the deer that got Covid-19 and even an exhibit of 500,000 leafcutter ants. Animals, she said, are one of her main beats as a science reporter. So when she visited a chimpanzee sanctuary in June, she couldn’t ignore the connections between human nature and animal instinct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Nayeri
title: A ‘Digital Heist’ Recaptures the Rosetta Stone
description: The collective Looty in London virtually reclaims items from Western museums to give people from former colonies a chance to learn about their stolen heritage.
content: The Rosetta Stone is to the British Museum what the Mona Lisa is to the Louvre. Every day, throngs of visitors to the London museum take smartphone snaps of the etched black slab that was seized from Egypt over 200 years ago and never went back. Except that, in the next month, the Rosetta Stone is returning home — in a manner of speaking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass and Mikael Olsson
title: In the Swedish Countryside, a Home With Space to Think
description: A creative couple have transformed a former schoolhouse into a minimalist live-work space that spurs their art — and reflects it, too.
content: SWEDEN IS AMONG the world’s most egalitarian societies, but you might not sense that when surveying the ancestral estates that rise above the gently rolling landscape of the southern Skåne province, near the country’s border with Denmark. Among them is the 14th-century Högestad, outside of the town of Ystad, which has been owned for the last 300 years by descendants of Count Carl Piper, a nobleman who purchased the agricultural spread around 1705. His wife, Christina, who died in 1752, was one of the most successful entrepreneurs and real estate developers of her time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: Goldman’s C.E.O. Is Stuck, Without a Clear Lifeline
description: David Solomon’s management style is winning few fans amid the elite investment bank’s performance woes. He is mired in “quicksand” and unsure what to do.
content: One day in mid-June, Lloyd Blankfein called David Solomon, chief executive of Goldman Sachs. Mr. Solomon had not been expecting it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Outrage as Chinese Real Estate Giant Wobbles and Its Stock Dives
description: Financial troubles at Country Garden, the last big developer to avoid default, set off panic in the markets and angry comments on social media.
content: It was considered the gold standard in China’s increasingly shaky housing market. Now investors are treating Country Garden, the giant developer, as if it were a ticking time bomb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Spain Goes the Distance to Reach Its First Women’s World Cup Semifinal
description: Salma Paralluelo’s goal in extra time delivered a victory over the Netherlands and a date with Sweden.
content: Salma Paralluelo might not have chosen soccer. It was not her only option, certainly. A 19-year-old Spain striker, Paralluelo was a bright prospect in track and field, too, such a gifted runner that she might even have represented her country at the Tokyo Olympics two years ago. Her chosen discipline was the 400 meters. She still holds the national under-20 record at the distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Mann
title: The Perseids Meteor Shower, One of the Year’s Best, Is Reaching Its Peak
description: The event is formed from debris left by the comet 109P/Swift-Tuttle, and the summer weather could make it a very good show.
content: On any given night, far from bright city lights, there’s a chance that you’ll see a beautiful streak shoot across the sky as a meteor flies overhead. But on special dates scattered throughout the year, skywatchers can catch a multitude of flares as meteor showers burst in the darkness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Richard J. Whalen, Biographer of Joseph P. Kennedy, Dies at 87
description: His book about the patriarch of the Kennedy political dynasty was a best seller. He later worked, briefly and not happily, for Richard M. Nixon.
content: Richard J. Whalen, who in his diverse career wrote a best-selling biography of Joseph P. Kennedy, the patriarch of the Democratic political dynasty, before joining Richard M. Nixon’s 1968 presidential campaign as a speechwriter — but who left before the election and wrote a critical book about him — died on July 18 in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Why Naming Weiss Special Counsel in the Hunter Biden Case May Not Change Much
description: Special counsel status essentially formalizes a degree of independence the prosecutor already had.
content: One oddity about Attorney General Merrick B. Garland’s decision to give special counsel status to David Weiss, the Trump-appointed U.S. attorney for Delaware who has been leading the investigation into President Biden’s son Hunter, is that both Mr. Garland and Mr. Weiss have already said the prosecutor was empowered to act independently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Who Is David Weiss, the U.S. Attorney Elevated to Special Counsel?
description: He earned the support of both of Delaware’s Democratic senators when then-President Trump, now a critic, nominated him in late 2017.
content: The Hunter Biden case is an unexpected career turn for David C. Weiss, a tough, workmanlike prosecutor and commercial lawyer whose stubborn competitiveness earned him a reputation as a hard man to strike out in local softball leagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Clare Toeniskoetter, Sydney Harper, Olivia Natt, Carlos Prieto, M.J. Davis Lin, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong, Elisheba Ittoop, Rowan Niemisto, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: The End of an Era for U.S. Women’s Soccer
description: The reigning champions’ exit from the World Cup signaled a revolution for the sport.
content: A few days ago, when the U.S. team was eliminated from the FIFA Women’s World Cup, it marked the end of a history-making run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Wildfires’ Mounting Death Toll in Maui, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein
title: Sam Bankman-Fried Sent to Jail After Judge Revokes Bail
description: Mr. Bankman-Fried had been under house arrest at his parents’ home as he awaited trial on charges stemming from the collapse of his cryptocurrency company, FTX.
content: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the collapsed cryptocurrency exchange FTX, was sent to jail on Friday after a federal judge in New York revoked his bail, accusing him of trying to influence witnesses who are poised to testify against him at a widely anticipated trial in less than two months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Air Taxi Rivals End Legal Fight and Agree to Collaborate
description: Wisk Aero, owned by Boeing, entered a financial and technological partnership with Archer Aviation and dropped a lawsuit claiming theft of trade secrets.
content: Two rivals in the race to mass-produce an all-electric aircraft said on Thursday that they had agreed to collaborate and settled a trade-secrets lawsuit that one rival, Wisk Aero, had filed against the other, Archer Aviation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay, Derek Arthur and Phoebe Lett
title: Summer by the Pool Should Be a Right, Not a Privilege
description: Mara Gay wants you to go swimming. Safely.
content: America has an uneasy relationship with water. More than half of Americans don’t know how to swim or how to swim well. Eleven people in the United States die every day from drowning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Stevens
title: Unusual Suspects
description: These mysteries run the gamut, from quirky Gothic to small-town cozy to chilly Nordic noir.
content: Every child is a detective. It comes with the territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Jacob Zuma Released After Brief Return to Prison in South Africa
description: The authorities said Mr. Zuma, the former president, was a beneficiary of a new program to relieve crowding. His political opponents called the timing suspicious.
content: Former President Jacob Zuma of South Africa returned to prison early Friday morning to continue serving a sentence for contempt, but was released almost immediately under a program to relieve overcrowding in the country’s jails, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Here Are Past U.S. Wildfires That Turned Especially Deadly.
description: The search for victims from the wildfires in Maui this week has evoked painful memories of fatal blazes on the mainland.
content: The urgent search for victims of the wildfires in Maui this week has evoked painful memories of dozens of other fatal blazes that have seared the American landscape, especially in the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By LaVonne Ellis
title: Never Give Your Child Five Names
description: If you do, he may never be able to leave you.
content: Thirty-six years ago, heavy with child, I argued with my husband about what to name the baby. We knew it was a boy and eventually settled on a first name of Robin — Robby for short — after my husband’s sister, after one of my best friends (and silently, just in my head, after the first boy I ever danced with). And Robin Williams, of course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler and Ephrat Livni
title: Why the Fed Might not Be Done Raising Rates
description: Volatile energy prices could put new pressures on the economy, despite some cautious optimism after the latest inflation data.
content: The futures market this morning is overwhelmingly pointing to a big pause by the Fed at its rate-setting meeting next month as inflation moderates. But, as some Fed officials warn, it’s too early to declare mission accomplished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Why Bonds Are Still Essential Investments
description: Even after the latest U.S. debt downgrade, bonds remain the steadier counterpart to the flamboyant stock market, our columnist says.
content: Give the stock market half a chance and it will dominate the financial headlines. That was certainly the case for the month of July, with the S&P 500 powering upward and bonds barely treading water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: An Eccentric Victorian, His Book and the Giant Pink Pastry of a House He Inspired
description: In “The Octagon House,” published in 1848, Orson Squire Fowler wondered why anyone would build a four-sided home when they could have an eight-sided one.
content: Has any man in history loved anything as much as Orson Squire Fowler loved the octagon? Fowler, born in Cohocton, N.Y., in 1809, published a book in 1848 arguing that all houses should be eight-sided. He influenced a (failed) utopian community in Kansas called Octagon City, delivered an estimated 350 public orations on octagon supremacy and built himself a 60-room octagonal palace in upstate New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hisako Ueno and Mike Ives
title: This Candy Tasted Like Nothing. Why Do People Miss It?
description: Flavorless (?) Candy, a convenience store product in Japan, spurred debate over what the “taste of nothingness” tastes like, if anything.
content: A flavorless candy appeared briefly in Japanese convenience stores and may never be sold again. We consider this news.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: With Breathtaking Speed, Blast of Fire Erases a Town in Hawaii
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 11, 2023.
content: “The fire was just traveling too fast, and too hot and next thing you know Lahaina town is gone, literally gone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: From films with swift swordplay to those with mega-tornadoes, this month’s action picks go big.
content: Though Jaeda King (Naturi Naughton) practices martial arts, she isn’t your prototypical hero. The married mother is a judge, and she’s presiding over the biggest case of her career. Despite his pleas of innocence, Sean Samuels (Jason Mitchell) has already been convicted of murder and his sentencing is imminent. However, Sean’s brother, Gabriel (Lance Gross), isn’t waiting for the outcome. Armed with a fleet of gunmen, Gabriel, a.k.a. Black Caesar, storms the courthouse to spring Sean. And Jaeda — let’s call her King — uses more than her gavel to fight back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Special counsel appointed in Hunter Biden case
description: This weekend, turn your eyes to the stars.
content: Attorney General Merrick Garland elevated David Weiss, the federal prosecutor investigating President Biden’s son Hunter, to special counsel status. It was a stunning reversal for Garland, who last month had brushed off the idea of appointing Weiss to the role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leslie Katz
title: When the Matchmaker Made Herself the Perfect Match
description: Emily Dobies wanted to set up Sal Steiner, a co-worker, with a mutual friend seven years ago. But Ms. Dobies and Mr. Steiner were more interested in each other.
content: The night Emily Kate Dobies and Sal Steiner shared their first kiss in 2016, Ms. Dobies had been trying to orchestrate a match between Mr. Steiner and a mutual friend. The friend was in a troubled relationship, and Ms. Dobies thought that Mr. Steiner, with his warmth and honesty, could remind her that good dating prospects still existed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: Once a Child Star, She Now Leads ‘Murder Tours’ in Hollywood
description: In Halley Sutton’s “The Hurricane Blonde,” a young woman struggles with the decades-old, still unsolved murder of her sister.
content: Salma Lowe, born into Hollywood royalty, has been through it. Before the murder of her older sister Tawney sent her spiraling into grief-fueled drug addiction 20 years earlier, Salma was a child actor on the cusp of stardom. Now, as Halley Sutton’s enthralling THE HURRICANE BLONDE (Putnam, 347 pp., paperback, $17.99) opens, Salma works for a company called Stars Six Feet Under, conducting tours of the houses where starlets lived and died in violent circumstances for “murder tourists.” Is it avoidance or deep immersion? Salma isn’t sure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Making Wedding Plans Before the First Date
description: Melissa D’Andrea and Karissa Sullivan, who matched on the dating app Her, were instantly attracted to each other. Five months after meeting, they were engaged.
content: Melissa Jeanne D’Andrea had already envisioned a future with Karissa Heleene Sullivan before they met. “I picked out our wedding hashtag before our first date,” Ms. D’Andrea said. It was a play on both their names: #issawedding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Infant Was Decapitated During Delivery, Georgia Couple’s Lawsuit Claims
description: A complaint says an obstetrician used too much force during the delivery and that a hospital had tried to conceal what had happened.
content: A Georgia couple filed a lawsuit this week against a doctor, hospital and nurses involved in the delivery of their first child, claiming that an obstetrician had used too much force during the procedure, resulting in the decapitation and death of their baby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Illinois Supreme Court Clears Way for State’s Sharp Gun Limits
description: The court found that a ban on AR-15-style rifles did not violate the State Constitution. More legal challenges are assured.
content: The Illinois Supreme Court on Friday upheld the state’s ban on certain high-powered guns, including AR-15-style rifles, a major victory for supporters of gun limits in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: A Bloodless Postscript to ‘Jaws’ in ‘The Shark Is Broken’
description: Just when you thought it was safe to go back in the theater, a play about the making of Hollywood’s first summer blockbuster bobs up on Broadway.
content: For nine weeks in 1974, off the shore of Martha’s Vineyard, the shooting of “Jaws” was repeatedly delayed by the whims of its temperamental stars. And by “stars,” I mean Bruce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Ukraine Fires Top Military Enlistment Officers After Bribery Scandal
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said he was removing all 24 regional recruitment chiefs, as corrupt draft evasion schemes put the confidence of the public and Ukraine’s Western backers at risk.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine announced on Friday that his government was dismissing all of the country’s regional military recruitment chiefs to crack down on corruption, after multiple revelations of officers taking bribes to let men evade being drafted into fighting the Russian invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Olivia Rodrigo’s Sassy Pop-Rock Banger and 8 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Noname, Ian Sweet, Miguel and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: Spiraling Legal Bills Threaten Trump With a Cash Crunch
description: The former president’s political orbit, including the super PAC that backs him, is already spending more than it is taking in — an unusual trajectory this far out from an election.
content: Donald J. Trump’s legal problems aren’t just piling up — his legal bills are, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: G.O.P. Candidates Try to Capture Iowa Attention in the Absence of Trump
description: With Donald J. Trump still en route to the state fair, Republican candidates hope to connect with Iowa voters before the former president grabs the spotlight.
content: The butter cow is carved. The pork chops are prepped. And the candidates who weren’t at the Iowa State Fair on Thursday are on their way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Does God Control History?
description: Debating providence with Bronze Age Pervert.
content: After last week’s newsletter made the case for the wickedness of Stalinism and the virtues of early Cold War anti-Communism, I thought I might get dragged into a weekend social media debate about Marxism-Leninism. Not so. Instead, I managed to entangle myself in an argument about a different totalitarianism-related question: whether the destruction of Hitler’s Germany was a true and righteous judgment of Almighty God.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Survivor Recounts Escape From Hawaii Wildfires
description: Bill Wyland, a resident, fled the flames in Lahaina, Hawaii, on his motorcycle. “I don’t know how people are going to live now,” he said, describing the wildfires’ devastation.
